title: Confirm Fe (Dominant)
intro: Answer based on long-term patterns across years and contexts. Use 4–5 only if it’s consistently true. Fe-dominant is self-determination through the social world: tracking emotional atmosphere, shaping interaction norms, and creating cooperation by maintaining connection and shared morale (not simply “being nice”).

items.text: I automatically track the emotional atmosphere (tension, comfort, inclusion) and it affects how I act in the moment.
examples: I notice mood shifts before people name them.
I adjust my tone to reduce awkwardness or strain.
I can sense when someone feels left out or uneasy.
I feel responsible to ‘steady’ the room when it’s off.

items.text: I evaluate behavior by whether it supports connection and mutual respect. I feel discomfort when interactions become cold, harsh, or humiliating.
examples: I dislike environments where people shame or ridicule each other.
I care about fairness in how people are treated publicly.
I try to prevent someone from losing face unnecessarily.
Cruel honesty without care feels wrong to me.

items.text: In conflict, I look for dialogue and compromise to restore cooperation, even if I have to be the one to initiate it.
examples: I try to translate between people so they understand each other.
I prefer ‘repairing’ the relationship over winning the argument.
I look for a solution that everyone can accept.
I find it hard to ignore relational tension for long.

items.text: I feel most stable when there’s emotional connection. When I’m low, I naturally seek support/affirmation—or feel the lack of it strongly.
examples: Loneliness or disconnection hits me hard.
Kind reassurance helps me recover quickly.
I worry about being disliked or rejected more than being wrong.
I’m sensitive to social coldness or being excluded.

items.text: I actively include people and think about what others need emotionally, even when nobody asks.
examples: I check in on people’s feelings by default.
I remember small social details to keep warmth.
I organize harmony: introductions, shared activities, morale.
I often become the ‘social glue’ without intending to.

items.text: People sometimes say I over-involve myself, people-please, or ‘manage’ the social field too much—even when I’m trying to keep things humane.
examples: I’ve been told I worry too much about what others think.
I feel guilty if someone is upset around me.
I sometimes speak for the group or assume feelings too quickly.
I can struggle with boundaries when helping.

items.text: I rarely notice emotional cues or social norms; I’m comfortable ignoring atmosphere and doing my own thing.
examples: I often miss tension, discomfort, or exclusion until told directly.
I don’t care much if others feel awkward around me.
I dislike ‘reading the room’ and see it as unnecessary.
I prioritize my goals even if it makes the room uncomfortable.

items.text: I treat relationships as mostly transactional; usefulness matters more than emotional connection or shared morale.
examples: I keep people mainly if they provide value.
I don’t feel responsible for others’ feelings.
I dislike emotional caretaking and avoid it.
I rarely seek emotional support from others.

items.text: I prioritize personal preference/authenticity over social harmony; I’d rather be true to myself than adapt for the group.
examples: I dislike conforming or smoothing things over.
I say what I feel even if it disrupts harmony.
I resist social expectations if they conflict with my values.
I don’t try to make things ‘comfortable’ if it feels fake.

items.text: In stressful situations, I become colder and more detached; connection doesn’t help me much compared to solving the problem alone.
examples: When stressed, I withdraw rather than seek people.
I prefer private processing to talking it out.
Comfort doesn’t change much for me; solutions do.
I can ignore relational tension if the task matters.
